Literature Review: Gluconeogenesis is a vital metabolic pathway that maintains whole-body glucose homeostasis. However, its flux is often altered in various metabolic diseases, leading to significant changes in glucose metabolism and contributing to disease pathogenesis. This literature review aims to summarize the current understanding of gluconeogenic flux in different medical diseases, including common metabolic disorders, hormonal imbalances, specific inborn genetic errors, and cancer. We will discuss the changes in circulating levels of available gluconeogenesis substrates and the efficiency of converting those substrates to glucose by gluconeogenic organs, using data from experiments using isotopic tracer and spectroscopy methodologies. Our review will also highlight ongoing knowledge gaps, emerging research areas, and suggest future investigations to identify novel and targeted treatment strategies for these diseases.
